boardgame.name: Fantasy Football: Draft, Deals, and Dice
boardgame.description:
Fantasy Football: Draft, Deals, and Dice (FF3D) is a card drafting and dice rolling game that allows players to simulate the fantasy football experience. FF3D is designed to be played with 2 or 4 players, though expansions can easily allow up to 16 players. FF3D can be played in anywhere from 60-120 minutes, depending on the length of time players spend on their initial drafting process.

The base game of Fantasy Football: Draft, Deals, and Dice allows players to compete with each other over a shortened four week fantasy football season. The Owners have the opportunity to draft their fantasy rosters from a pool of randomized Players at the start of the season. The Team and Player Ratings are randomized at the start of each season, so no two seasons will ever be the same. One year, the San Francisco QB could be a star player with major upside – the next year, he could be a mediocre talent that shrinks in the Primetime. The winner is able to initially assess the random market conditions of the league to maximize their draft selections within their roster restrictions, as well as able to navigate the flow of the season’s Defensive Matchups, Injuries, Hot Streaks better than their opponents.

After establishing agreed upon Roster Requirements for the League, the game begins with (and features) everyone’s favorite part of the fantasy football season – the fantasy draft.

The Game is split into three main segments:
The Fantasy Draft
The Regular Season
The Playoffs

Owners will draft a team of Players and set their starting lineups against the opposing Owner on their Fantasy Schedule. The Owners take turns determining their Weekly Results by rolling a specified number of Offensive and Defensive dice for each Player in their Starting Lineup. The number and types of dice rolled are influenced by the Player's Skill and Upside Levels, as well as any Team Matchup Modifiers, Player Hot Streaks, or Player Injuries that have been assigned to the player during the game play. In-Game Events could also trigger unexpected outcomes that can swing the momentum during a game. After all games have been played, the Owner with the most points in the matchup receives the win. At the end of each week, Players are randomly selected to either go on a Hot Streak or go on the Injured Reserve. Owners may replace Injured players by following a Waiver and Free Agency process against the other Owners to select Players from the pool of unselected Players from the initial draft. The first three weeks make up the Regular Season, with the Top 2 teams competing in Week 4 for the Championship.

boardgame.name: St. Kitts
boardgame.description:
Some history. The vervets monkeys arrived from Africa to the Caribbean island of St. Kitts with slaves of the rum industry 300 years ago. The monkeys that escaped, acquired taste (and addiction) for alcohol eating fermented sugarcane.

These funny monkeys, good observers of man, they know, like the locals, that the easiest way to get your daily dose of alcohol is by distracted tourists in the beach bars. They love cocktails, daiquiris, caipirinhas, usually rum-based drinks.

In St. Kitts each player is a waiter who is held to be more cocktails (of each type) serving in a beach snack bar, trying to fill their tables of wealthy and thirsty tourists.

All actions are carried away and combining results of dice. Refer to vervets monkeys, bartenders and cocktails. If you get a result of blue, red, green or yellow refers to a cocktail. They come in four types: Daikiri strawberries (red cocktail), Caipirinha (green cocktail), Banana colada (yellow cocktail) and Blue Ocean (Blue cocktail). Place a record of your color in a table that asks that cocktail to indicate that you've served you, according to rules.

Each full table you've served more cocktails (you have most) awards (knizian) points to the end of the game. If you can add new tables to serve more tourists you will receive tips.

And if that were not enough, we must be aware of groups vervets monkeys in their usual "raids" in search of alcohol miss these tips will make acquired with sweat and tears.

Rival witch covens have been warring for the souls of Ipswich's townsfolk for years, but it ends now. You’ve been tasked to search home by home to find the witches and end this feud.

Cunning Folk is a micro game of bluffing and deduction. You are townsfolk, investigating the houses of Ipswich for witches, good and evil. boardgame.description:
“Zombies are just the start of your troubles.”

All Things Zombie: Reloaded is the expanded 2nd edition of our original All Things Zombie: Reloaded board game. Designer and Developer Ed Teixeira has developed his zombie world, so it’s not just the zombies you need to worry about.

Before you were fighting zombies; now you have to work with and against the other human Survivors, Militia, and Gangers. Now you must learn how to survive and thrive in this dangerous and ever-changing world.

A set of Event Cards that provide all the info you need at a glance, from friends, enemies, zombies, loot and more.
Newly designed Player Aid cards to help you keep track of your characters and their “stuff”.
An easy to use campaign system that ties all your games together where the results of one affect the results of the next.
Six 11” x 17” maps that can be laid out in over 50 different ways, making each game unique.
Specific objectives that provide ways for your characters to increase in skill and ability when they succeed.
All this and more.


All Things Zombie: Reloaded can be played solitaire, cooperatively with everyone on the same side, or competitively with everyone against one another. All Things Zombie: Reloaded can be played as a “one off game” or part of an ongoing campaign.

boardgame.name: Command & Conquer: Tiberium
Tiberium
boardgame.description:
UNRELEASED GAME - CANCELLED




This game was cancelled in development. Please only submit images if you own a copy or have legal access to this item.




Tiberium was a title set in the Command & Conquer universe, and was initially revealed when shots of the January 2008 issue of Game Informer were leaked, but was officially announced by EA just a day after. Prior to the announcement, the game had been in production for two years. The plot would have revolved around a repeat invasion of Scrin, shown from the eyes of a GDI commando. It would have been, to date, the only C&C game not to include "Command & Conquer" in its title.

Tiberium was canceled on September 30, 2008 due to the game's failure to meet "quality standards set by the development team and the EA Games label". Kotaku reported Mariam Sughayer, EA spokesperson, saying "EA has suspended work on Tiberium effective immediately. The game was not on track to meet the high quality standards set by the team and by the EA Games Label. A lower quality game is not in the best interest of the consumers and would not succeed in this market."

Source: Wikipedia, "List of canceled Command & Conquer games", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Sadness
boardgame.description:
UNRELEASED GAME - CANCELLED




This game was cancelled in development. Please only submit images if you own a copy or have legal access to this item.




Sadness was in development for the Wii console and was one of the earliest titles announced for the system. While the game initially drew positive attention for its unique gameplay concepts, such as black-and-white graphics and emphasis on psychological horror over violence, Sadness became notorious when no evidence of a playable build was ever publicly released during the four years it spent in development. It was revealed that Sadness had entered development hell due to problems with deadlines and relationships with external developers, leading to its eventual cancellation by 2010, along with the permanent closure of the company.

Set in pre-World War I Ukraine, Sadness was to follow the player character Maria Lengyel, a Victorian era aristocrat of Polish-Hungarian descent who has to protect her son Alexander after their train to Lviv derails in the countryside. Alexander, who is struck blind by the accident, begins to exhibit strange behavior that progressively worsens. The game's scenarios and enemies, such as those based on the werewolf and the likho, are inspired by Slavic mythology. In order to "make the player feel that he is participating in events [and] not merely playing a game," the game was planned to feature a branching storyline, influenced by the player's actions and concluding with one out of ten possible endings.

Source: Wikipedia, "Sadness (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: B.C.
boardgame.description:
UNRELEASED GAME - CANCELLED




This game was cancelled in development. Please only submit images if you own a copy or have legal access to this item.




B.C. was cancelled in 2004 for unknown reasons. B.C. was going to take place during a prehistoric time period on a single continent which contained five levels. The player controls a tribe who has to evolve and migrate to become the best species in the game. Tribe members can be of different classes and each can level up different ways to evolve. The main enemies in the game are an ape-like creature called the "simians"; however, the world is also inhabited with many types of dinosaurs as well as other creatures, including the dodo.

Even while the game was still in production, Molyneux said that he was unsure when he could release it due to "the ambitious nature of the gameplay and the high standards the people developing it are pushing for." According to one article, as of May, 2002, "[the demo build] was roughly 50 percent complete". Its cancellation was announced in late 2004 with Molyneux saying, "The decision to suspend work on any games project is always a very difficult one, particularly when it is a title with the potential of BC."

Source: Wikipedia, "BC (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Shenmue 3

Shenmue III
boardgame.description:
User Summary

Shenmue III was formally a canceled game for the Dreamcast created by Sega. Various unconfirmed reasons for its delay include budget issues, poor sales of Shenmue II, and creative differences between Yu Suzuki and the more conservative management Sega installed. Shenmue III has been announced and cancelled at least twice. It was originally set to contain Shenmue I and II.

With a successful KickStarter in 2015, Shenmue 3 has started development again and is partially funded by Sony. Shenmue 3 has been created for the PC and PlayStation 4 and built in Unreal 4. It will will have familiar elements from its predecessors and new fight mechanics to achieve a new level of interactive storytelling. The story continues as Ryo and Shenhua travel farther into enemy territory.

Steam version is set to be available in November 2020, but the game is available on other platforms as well as on Epic Games for Windows.
